Barack Obama has been winding down after eight years in the White House with a spot of kite-surfing with his buddy and billionaire Sir Richard Branson. 
The former POTUS reportedly spent two days learning the basics of how to fly a kite on dry land before his was finally allowed to graduate to the water. 
Despite numerous security guard circling around the retired President, Obama was able to "relax and get into it," according to Branson. 
Speaking on his blog, Richard Branson wrote: "It was a huge honour to be able to invite President Barack and Michelle Obama down to the British Virgin Islands for a complete break after Barack finished his second term as President and the family left the White House. Barack Obama learning to kitesurf on the British Virgin Islands (Photo: Jack Brockway/Virgin.com) 
"So it was tremendous to offer him the chance to learn to kitesurf. 
"The sport has really taken off in the past decade and we have the perfect conditions and team to help anyone learn. 
"I have also wanted to learn foilboard surfing. So we decided to set up a friendly challenge: could Barack learn to kitesurf before I learned to foilboard? The former POTUS quickly picked up the basics (Photo: Jack Brockway/Virgin.com) Obama was challenged to a race by Richard Branson (Photo: Jack Brockway/Virgin.com) 
"We agreed to have a final day battle to see who could stay up the longest." 
Turns out, Obama was victorious in the challenge, despite falling off his board a fair few times in the lead up to the race. 
Branson added: "After all he has done for the world, I couldnâ€™t begrudge him his well-deserved win." Read More Barack and Michelle Obama enjoy well-earned holiday with Richard Branson The former POTUS came out on top in the end (Photo: Jack Brockway/Virgin.com) 
After handing over the Presidential reins to Donald Trump, Obama, 55, and his family flew to Palm Springs for a long weekend before heading to the British Virgin Islands. 
The Obamas arrived in the Virgin Islands on Branson's private jet last Monday, MailOnline reported.
